slides.title: Welcome to Organic Chemistry
slides.content:
# Introduction to Organic Chemistry

Welcome to **Organic Chemistry** - the study of carbon-containing compounds!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Hydrocarbons** - Compounds of C and H only
- **Functional Groups** - Reactive parts of molecules
- **IUPAC Naming** - Systematic nomenclature
- **Polymers** - Long chain molecules
- **Biomolecules** - Molecules of life

> **Fun Fact:** There are more organic compounds than all other types combined - over 10 million known!

## Why Organic Chemistry Matters:
- All living things are made of organic compounds
- Medicines, plastics, fuels are organic
- Food, clothing, cosmetics
- Understanding biochemistry

## Carbon's Unique Properties:

| Property | Significance |
|----------|-------------|
| 4 bonds | Forms many compounds |
| Catenation | C-C chains possible |
| Small size | Strong bonds |
| Electronegativity | Stable bonds with many elements |

slides.title: Hydrocarbons: Alkanes
slides.content:
# Alkanes

**Alkanes** are saturated hydrocarbons with only single bonds.

## General Formula: CnH2n+2

## First Ten Alkanes:

| Name | Formula | Carbons |
|------|---------|--------|
| Methane | CH4 | 1 |
| Ethane | C2H6 | 2 |
| Propane | C3H8 | 3 |
| Butane | C4H10 | 4 |
| Pentane | C5H12 | 5 |
| Hexane | C6H14 | 6 |
| Heptane | C7H16 | 7 |
| Octane | C8H18 | 8 |
| Nonane | C9H20 | 9 |
| Decane | C10H22 | 10 |

## Properties:
- Low reactivity (saturated)
- Burn in oxygen (combustion)
- Insoluble in water
- Boiling point increases with chain length

## Isomers:

Same formula, different structure.

C4H10 has 2 isomers:
- n-butane (straight chain)
- isobutane (branched)

> **Fuel:** Natural gas is mainly methane, LPG is propane/butane.

slides.title: Alkenes and Alkynes
slides.content:
# Alkenes and Alkynes

## Alkenes (C=C double bond)

**General Formula:** CnH2n

| Name | Formula |
|------|--------|
| Ethene | C2H4 |
| Propene | C3H6 |
| Butene | C4H8 |

### Properties:
- Unsaturated (can add more atoms)
- More reactive than alkanes
- Undergo addition reactions

## Alkynes (C:::C triple bond)

**General Formula:** CnH2n-2

| Name | Formula |
|------|--------|
| Ethyne | C2H2 |
| Propyne | C3H4 |

## Reactions:

### Addition to Alkenes:
```
C2H4 + H2 -> C2H6 (hydrogenation)
C2H4 + Br2 -> C2H4Br2 (bromination)
C2H4 + H2O -> C2H5OH (hydration)
```

### Test for Unsaturation:
Bromine water: orange -> colorless

## Polymerization:

```
n(CH2=CH2) -> (-CH2-CH2-)n
Ethene -> Polyethene (plastic)
```

slides.title: Functional Groups
slides.content:
# Functional Groups

**Functional groups** determine chemical properties of organic compounds.

## Common Functional Groups:

| Group | Structure | Example |
|-------|-----------|--------|
| Alcohol | -OH | Ethanol (C2H5OH) |
| Aldehyde | -CHO | Methanal (HCHO) |
| Ketone | -CO- | Propanone (acetone) |
| Carboxylic acid | -COOH | Ethanoic acid (vinegar) |
| Ester | -COO- | Ethyl ethanoate |
| Amine | -NH2 | Methylamine |
| Amide | -CONH2 | Ethanamide |
| Ether | -O- | Diethyl ether |
| Halogenoalkane | -X | Chloromethane |

## Identifying Functional Groups:

Look for characteristic atoms:
- O-H: Alcohol or carboxylic acid
- C=O: Aldehyde, ketone, or carboxylic acid
- N: Amine or amide
- Halogen: Halogenoalkane

## Reactivity:

Functional groups are the reactive sites of molecules.

slides.title: Alcohols
slides.content:
# Alcohols

**Alcohols** contain the hydroxyl (-OH) group.

## Classification:

| Type | -OH attached to | Example |
|------|-----------------|--------|
| Primary (1) | C with 1 alkyl group | Ethanol |
| Secondary (2) | C with 2 alkyl groups | Propan-2-ol |
| Tertiary (3) | C with 3 alkyl groups | 2-methylpropan-2-ol |

## Naming:
- Replace -e with -ol
- Number position of -OH
- Example: CH3CH2OH = ethanol

## Reactions:

### Combustion:
```
C2H5OH + 3O2 -> 2CO2 + 3H2O
```

### Oxidation:
- Primary -> Aldehyde -> Carboxylic acid
- Secondary -> Ketone
- Tertiary -> Resistant to oxidation

### Dehydration:
```
C2H5OH -> C2H4 + H2O (heated with H2SO4)
```

### Esterification:
```
Alcohol + Acid -> Ester + Water
```

## Uses:
- Ethanol: Beverages, fuel, solvent
- Methanol: Industrial solvent
- Glycerol: Cosmetics, food

slides.title: Carboxylic Acids
slides.content:
# Carboxylic Acids

**Carboxylic acids** contain the -COOH group.

## Naming:
- Replace -e with -oic acid
- Example: CH3COOH = ethanoic acid (acetic acid)

## Common Carboxylic Acids:

| Name | Formula | Found in |
|------|---------|----------|
| Methanoic | HCOOH | Ant stings |
| Ethanoic | CH3COOH | Vinegar |
| Citric | C6H8O7 | Citrus fruits |
| Lactic | C3H6O3 | Sour milk |

## Properties:
- Weak acids (partially ionize)
- Sour taste
- React with metals, bases, carbonates

## Reactions:

### With metals:
```
2CH3COOH + Mg -> (CH3COO)2Mg + H2
```

### With bases:
```
CH3COOH + NaOH -> CH3COONa + H2O
```

### Esterification:
```
CH3COOH + C2H5OH -> CH3COOC2H5 + H2O
```

## Esters:
- Sweet/fruity smell
- Used in perfumes, flavorings
- Biodiesel is fatty acid esters

slides.title: IUPAC Nomenclature
slides.content:
# IUPAC Nomenclature

Systematic naming of organic compounds.

## Rules:

### 1. Find longest carbon chain:
This is the parent name.

### 2. Number carbons:
From end nearest to substituent/functional group.

### 3. Name substituents:
| Group | Name |
|-------|------|
| CH3- | methyl |
| C2H5- | ethyl |
| Cl- | chloro |
| Br- | bromo |
| OH- | hydroxy |

### 4. Assemble name:
Substituents (alphabetically) + parent + suffix

## Examples:

```
CH3-CH2-CH2-CH3 = butane
CH3-CH(CH3)-CH3 = 2-methylpropane
CH3-CH2-OH = ethanol
CH3-CHO = ethanal
CH3-COOH = ethanoic acid
```

## Common Suffixes:

| Compound | Suffix |
|----------|--------|
| Alkane | -ane |
| Alkene | -ene |
| Alkyne | -yne |
| Alcohol | -ol |
| Aldehyde | -al |
| Ketone | -one |
| Carboxylic acid | -oic acid |

slides.title: Polymers
slides.content:
# Polymers

**Polymers** are large molecules made of repeating units (monomers).

## Addition Polymers:

Unsaturated monomers join without losing atoms.

| Monomer | Polymer | Use |
|---------|---------|-----|
| Ethene | Polyethene | Bags, bottles |
| Propene | Polypropene | Rope, containers |
| Styrene | Polystyrene | Packaging |
| Chloroethene | PVC | Pipes, flooring |
| Tetrafluoroethene | PTFE (Teflon) | Non-stick |

## Condensation Polymers:

Monomers join with loss of small molecule (usually H2O).

| Polymer | Monomers | Use |
|---------|----------|-----|
| Nylon | Diamine + diacid | Clothing, rope |
| Polyester | Diol + diacid | Clothing, bottles |
| Proteins | Amino acids | Biological |

## Properties:

| Type | Properties |
|------|------------|
| Thermoplastic | Softens on heating, recyclable |
| Thermosetting | Does not soften, stronger |

## Environmental Issues:
- Non-biodegradable
- Microplastics
- Recycling important
- Bioplastics being developed

slides.title: Proteins
slides.content:
# Proteins

**Proteins** are polymers of amino acids.

## Amino Acids:

General structure:
- Amino group (-NH2)
- Carboxylic acid group (-COOH)
- R group (side chain)

20 different amino acids in proteins.

## Peptide Bond:

```
-CO-NH- (amide bond)
```

Formed by condensation between amino acids.

## Protein Structure:

| Level | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| Primary | Amino acid sequence |
| Secondary | Alpha helix, beta sheet |
| Tertiary | 3D folded shape |
| Quaternary | Multiple polypeptide chains |

## Functions:

| Function | Example |
|----------|--------|
| Enzymes | Amylase, catalase |
| Structure | Collagen, keratin |
| Transport | Hemoglobin |
| Defense | Antibodies |
| Hormones | Insulin |

## Denaturation:

Loss of 3D structure due to:
- Heat
- pH change
- Chemicals

> **Example:** Cooking egg - proteins denature and solidify.

slides.title: Carbohydrates
slides.content:
# Carbohydrates

**Carbohydrates** contain C, H, and O in ratio Cn(H2O)m.

## Classification:

### Monosaccharides (simple sugars):
| Name | Formula | Source |
|------|---------|--------|
| Glucose | C6H12O6 | Fruits, blood |
| Fructose | C6H12O6 | Fruits, honey |
| Galactose | C6H12O6 | Milk |

### Disaccharides (two monosaccharides):
| Name | Components | Source |
|------|------------|--------|
| Sucrose | Glucose + Fructose | Table sugar |
| Maltose | Glucose + Glucose | Malt |
| Lactose | Glucose + Galactose | Milk |

### Polysaccharides (many monosaccharides):
| Name | Function |
|------|----------|
| Starch | Energy storage (plants) |
| Glycogen | Energy storage (animals) |
| Cellulose | Structure (plant cell walls) |

## Glycosidic Bond:

Links monosaccharides together.

## Tests:

| Test | Positive Result | Detects |
|------|----------------|--------|
| Benedict's | Orange ppt | Reducing sugars |
| Iodine | Blue-black | Starch |

slides.title: Lipids and Fats
slides.content:
# Lipids and Fats

**Lipids** are fats and oils - esters of fatty acids and glycerol.

## Structure:

Glycerol + 3 Fatty acids -> Triglyceride + 3 H2O

## Types of Fatty Acids:

| Type | Bonds | Example |
|------|-------|--------|
| Saturated | No C=C | Stearic acid |
| Unsaturated | Has C=C | Oleic acid |
| Polyunsaturated | Multiple C=C | Linoleic acid |

## Fats vs Oils:

| Property | Fats | Oils |
|----------|------|------|
| State at RT | Solid | Liquid |
| Source | Animal | Plant |
| Fatty acids | Saturated | Unsaturated |

## Reactions:

### Hydrolysis (saponification):
```
Fat + NaOH -> Glycerol + Soap (sodium salt of fatty acid)
```

### Hydrogenation:
```
Oil + H2 -> Fat (solid)
```

## Functions:
- Energy storage (9 kcal/g)
- Insulation
- Protection
- Cell membranes (phospholipids)

slides.title: Isomerism
slides.content:
# Isomerism

**Isomers** have same molecular formula but different arrangements.

## Structural Isomers:

Different connectivity of atoms.

### Chain Isomers:
Different carbon skeleton.
```
C4H10: n-butane, isobutane
```

### Position Isomers:
Same functional group, different position.
```
C3H7OH: propan-1-ol, propan-2-ol
```

### Functional Group Isomers:
Different functional groups.
```
C2H6O: ethanol (alcohol), dimethyl ether
```

## Stereoisomers:

Same connectivity, different spatial arrangement.

### Geometric (cis-trans) Isomers:
- Occur around C=C bond
- cis: same side
- trans: opposite sides

### Optical Isomers:
- Mirror images (enantiomers)
- Chiral center (4 different groups on C)
- Rotate plane-polarized light

## Importance:
- Different isomers can have different properties
- Important in drug design
- One isomer may be active, other inactive

slides.title: Reaction Types
slides.content:
# Organic Reaction Types

## Substitution:

One atom/group replaces another.

```
CH4 + Cl2 -> CH3Cl + HCl (UV light)
```

## Addition:

Atoms add across double/triple bond.

```
C2H4 + Br2 -> C2H4Br2
```

## Elimination:

Atoms removed to form double bond.

```
C2H5OH -> C2H4 + H2O (H2SO4, heat)
```

## Oxidation:

Addition of oxygen or removal of hydrogen.

```
C2H5OH -> CH3CHO -> CH3COOH
Alcohol -> Aldehyde -> Carboxylic acid
```

## Reduction:

Addition of hydrogen or removal of oxygen.

```
CH3CHO + H2 -> C2H5OH
```

## Condensation:

Two molecules join with loss of small molecule.

```
Alcohol + Acid -> Ester + H2O
```

## Hydrolysis:

Breaking with water.

```
Ester + H2O -> Alcohol + Acid
```

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Organic Chemistry Summary

## Hydrocarbons:

| Type | Bonds | Formula |
|------|-------|--------|
| Alkane | Single | CnH2n+2 |
| Alkene | Double | CnH2n |
| Alkyne | Triple | CnH2n-2 |

## Key Functional Groups:
- Alcohol: -OH
- Aldehyde: -CHO
- Ketone: -CO-
- Carboxylic acid: -COOH
- Ester: -COO-

## Biomolecules:

| Type | Monomers |
|------|----------|
| Proteins | Amino acids |
| Carbohydrates | Monosaccharides |
| Lipids | Fatty acids + glycerol |

## Reaction Types:
- Substitution, Addition, Elimination
- Oxidation, Reduction
- Condensation, Hydrolysis

## IUPAC Naming:
1. Find longest chain
2. Number from nearest substituent
3. Name substituents + parent + suffix

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Organic Chemistry!
